sn47.23:1.1: At one time the venerables Ānanda and Bhadda were staying near Pāṭaliputta, in the Chicken Monastery.
sn47.23:1.2: Then in the late afternoon, Venerable Bhadda came out of retreat, went to Venerable Ānanda, and exchanged greetings with him.
sn47.23:1.3: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to Ānanda:
sn47.23:1.4: “What’s the cause, Reverend Ānanda, what’s the reason why the true teaching declines?
sn47.23:1.5: And what’s the cause, what’s the reason why the true teaching doesn’t decline?”
sn47.23:2.2: Your approach and articulation are excellent, and it’s a good question.
sn47.23:2.4: ‘What’s the cause, what’s the reason why the true teaching declines?
sn47.23:2.5: And what’s the cause, what’s the reason why the true teaching doesn’t decline?’”
sn47.23:2.7: “It’s because of not developing and cultivating the four kinds of mindfulness meditation that the true teaching declines.
sn47.23:2.8: It’s because of developing and cultivating the four kinds of mindfulness meditation that the true teaching doesn’t decline.
sn47.23:3.2: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
sn47.23:3.3: They meditate observing an aspect of feelings …
sn47.23:3.5: principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
sn47.23:3.6: It’s because of not developing and cultivating these four kinds of mindfulness meditation that the true teaching declines.
sn47.23:3.7: And it’s because of developing and cultivating these four kinds of mindfulness meditation that the true teaching doesn’t decline.”
